I had the opportunity to drive one of Mercedes new E Series diesel engined cars for a few days, the same engine being used in Europe, and what a pleasant surprise. Same acceleration as the gasoline engine, virtually no noise level difference and 40+mpg. 
 
 After driving it, it isn't difficult to understand why diesel engined cars outsell gasoline engined cars in Europe by a large margin.
I have a recollection that mercedes diesel engines also run quite happily on vegetable oil, though don't quote me on that.

I'll probably go for the diesel engine when my wife's gasoline engined car is ready for replacement. We're not high mileage drivers in that mpg is a consideration, but if necessary I could probably run it for free as fuel reaches $10/gal with current administration foreign policy when considering the tremendous amount of vegetable oil our deep fried fast food, overweight society uses and discards. The smell of french fries and donuts could become overwhelming. 
 
 The biggest difference between Europe's diesel fuel and that consumed in the US is sulfur content. Sulfur is the primary air pollutant in diesel fuel. Europe (and Asia) refines their sulfur out, while the US is just getting around to that stage of environmental concern. I'm surprised current US administration, tied to the hip of energy companies, hasn't blocked that progress.
 
 We in the US also have a rather interesting tax situation with diesel fuel in that commercial transporters bearing a public utilities commission license pay from $.25-.50 USD less per gallon than private vehicles. The government rational for this spread is a fear of inflation upsetting the heavily lobbied transportation industry image (we're now a service economy), so citizens and small businesses make up the difference in required profit margins and federal fuel tax revenue. Our political system is very self-serving.

 The 2006 E Series diesel I drove has absolutely no relation to past Mercedes diesels. It was 28° this am when I started it, one turn of the key exactly as our gas engined cars. Inside and outside no difference in noise than gas engines. Just as fast from a dead stop on as the aluminum V6 with 25% better fuel mileage. I didn't sniff the tailpipe, but no obvious diesel smell. If this particular vehicle is a typical example, Mercedes has remedied all the reasons I would never buy one of their diesel passenger cars. I'll be very surprised if resale value suffers with this one. I can see a resale premium with the extra mpg factor. Especially if Bush attacks Iran.

Diesel prices at the pumps continue to be bad news, considerably higher than gasoline. This is not what you would expect, considering diesel is less expensive to refine. It's just that with the refineries being unable to keep up with demand, they have reserved more and more barrels for gasoline at the expense of diesel. This could be a long term problem, IMO.

We in the US also have a rather interesting tax situation with diesel fuel in that commercial transporters bearing a public utilities commission license pay from $.25-.50 USD less per gallon than private vehicles. Our political system is very self-serving.

 Pipedream. First, what is being produced at that $35 per barrel is not diesel fuel, it is a sweet crude that can be turned into diesel fuel. They do this in S Africa with an ingenious portable refining rig. You essentially pour in the raw syn crude and it craps out #2 and #3 diesel fuel and gasoline. It uses a catalyzing burner and burns off the light ends for the heat input for the reaction, which makes it entirely self contained. It is a slick setup. S Africa hs very little refining capability, and the mobile setups allow companies that just need fuel to essentially refine it on site, whihc is cheaper than buying imported refined goods. 
 
 Second, as the price of fuel rises, so does the cost of the process. It used to be that people claimed that $20 per barrel was the break evn point. Now it is $35 per barrel. If oil reaches $80 per barrel, the syn crude can be produced for $60 per barrel. The second problem is that Uranium production has probably already peaked. From http://www.worldenergy.org/wec-geis/publications/reports/ser/uranium/uranium.asp
 
 
World uranium requirements were about 61 600 tU in 1999 and are projected to lie within a range of 54 500 - 79 800 tU/year by 2015. The annual production capability in 1999 was 45 800 tU, or about 75% of requirements. Projections based on available capability developments and the phase-out of existing mines show that the capabilities for 2015 may range between 42 000 and 62 000 tU/year. 
 
 The total world uranium resources could supply ample quantities to cover the demands of existing and planned nuclear power stations over the next decade. However, because of the amount of anticipated supply from non-production sources, it is expected that mine production will continue to meet only a portion of the annual requirements over the next five to ten years. 
 
 Provided that non-production supplies continue to be available, the combination of mine and non-production supply could meet the requirements. However, if there is an unexpected interruption in supply a shortfall could develop. This could lead to unstable market conditions until the equilibrium between supply and demand is re-established.

 Ethanol is actually worse than coal. In addition to the fact that the ROEI on ethanol is only 4.5 (yes, that is using the new method), that ROEI does NOT include inorganic chemicals that are essentially required in the modern world to grow the feedstock in any decent quantity. Increased feedstock production costs (due to increased HC costs) really screws up the formula. Realistically, ethanol shares the problems of biomass gasification. Low density feed stock is expensive to transport. In order for the ROEI to remain reasonable, the plant can really only process feedstock form about a 10 mile radius.  If that is your concern, you may as well give up all hope now. Our food production is more petro intensive than anywhere else on the planet. We are only more petro intensive than Europe by about 5%. Our production is 4x more petro intensive than that of china, 6x that of other asian countries, and nearly 8x more petro intensive than most of S America. 
 
 This is one of those places where being a developed nation works against you in a BIG way. We have had the advantage of all the latest and greatest techno gizmos and gadgets, and as our society has evolved, it has been able to do so in an entirely unsustainable manner. Our population is primarily clustered in urban centers, with massive suburban spraw using up all the surrounding farmland. Using Kansas City for an example (because it is the example I know best), with oil at $110 per barrel, you can only produce enough food within a cost effective transport radius to feed about 40% of the population. This is KANSAS CITY we are talking about, surrounded by some fo the richest farm land in the nation and with relatively minimal urban sprawl. Can you imagin what those numbers would be like for New York? Even a mass exdus to the country is not a winning strategy because the fertilizers, pesticides, and herbicides that we use to grow our food are all petro based, and they travel great distances. Most fertilizers require at elast 11 steps for production and trravel nearly 2000 miles befroe they get to the store shelf. 
 
 Organic food production is no longer a choice in much of the country. It used to be that most farmland was broken up into homesteads, with fence rows and some natural cover. This natural cover provided habitat for birds and other animals that helped control the insect population. Most of that natural cover has been bulldozed over the last 40 years. Instead of an average unobstructed plot size of 85 acres, we have an average unobstructed plot size of 1200 acres. It would take 30 years to put that habitat back, and for animal populatiosn to increase to needed levels. Then, after you finally have some natural control for your bug problems, you are still trying to produce that food with fertilizers that cost 10-20x what they do today, using a tractor that burns through a lot of gas, and when you produce your crop, the transport costs make it a waste of time to send it to market, becuse nobody can afford it.

 Collector value. Scarcity and uniqueness is what created the value. I remember people calling junk yards to take them away for dismantling after sitting for years. Law enforcement agencies were virtually giving away their big block pursuit cars at auction after the first gas crisis in '73. Hemi Cudas were under $1k in the late '70s/early '80s. In 1981 I bought two complete Ford 429SCJ engines, pristine, for $250/ea. Within ten years the heads alone were worth $4k, blocks $3k. Police cars with 429CJs, C6 performance servo and clutch pack transmissions, etc. and 9" differentials having 31-spline straight axles were $500 for the entire car. Same with Chevy and Plymouth/Dodge. Could happen with today's SUVs, but I don't see anything unique about them to attract future attention. Other than trim, they're pretty much identically bland, though some will collect them just because of size.

 The few that were not parked in areas not visible to the public, awaiting their turn for the crusher.

Another barrier for future collectors is that due to EPA legislation, there are few actual vehicle boneyards left in the US. Most are now pic-a-part, where fairly current vehicles with no insurance repair component demand chops shops can't supply can sit for a limited period of time to keep the marginally poor in cheap parts before they go to the crusher. Where I live seeing semi trailers piled high with crushed cars headed up I-5 for the Port of Portland recyclers is a common sight. Once a year a traveling crusher visits our city. It sets up at the fairgrounds for a month crushing cars, metal appliances and other such objects, trucking out the remains. Future collectors will find it difficult to obtain that whatever SUV windshield containing obsolete electronics. Much less the parts made from now valuable components.
